title: New investor Del Vecchio challenges Mediobanca's strategy
text:
MILAN (Reuters) - Mediobanca (MDBI.MI) should rely less on contributions from the investment bank’s consumer credit unit and its stake in insurer Generali (GASI.MI) in a business plan due to be unveiled next month, shareholder Leonardo Del Vecchio said on Wednesday.

In his first comments about Mediobanca’s strategy since he snapped up a 7 percent stake in the bank last month, the eyewear tycoon said he expected the new plan to focus more on its investment banking business, boosting its role in Italy and Europe.

“I expect a new business plan that ensures Mediobanca does not rely only on Generali and Compass for its earnings but builds a future as an investment bank ... able to play a leading role in Italy and Europe,” said Del Vecchio, who is the executive chairman of Ray-Ban maker EssilorLuxottica (ESLX.PA).

His comments to Radiocor news agency were confirmed by a spokesman of his holding company, Delfin.

Mediobanca, which has been led by Chief Executive Alberto Nagel since 2008, is an outlier in Italy’s sluggish financial industry and in the last fiscal year booked its best revenues ever. Its wealth management and consumer businesses accounted for 60 percent of revenues in the year to end-June.

Analysts at Citi said in a recent report it has “better profitability than the system average, higher revenue growth, lower risk profile versus peers and solid capital”.

But a person familiar with Del Vecchio’s thinking said he believes the bank could be managed better, noting that its 13% stake in Generali accounts for about 30% of operating profit.

The person said Del Vecchio, who also holds a 5% stake in the insurer, wanted to change Mediobanca’s governance rule to ensure he will have a say in the choice of the next chief executive when Nagel’s mandate comes up for renewal next year.

Although his intentions are still unclear, three sources close to the situation said Del Vecchio aims, through his stake in Mediobanca, to engineer the future of Generali, including through possible cross-border deals.

Del Vecchio blames Nagel, and the insurer’s CEO, Philippe Donnet, for what he sees as Generali’s poor share price performance compared to rivals like Allianz (ALVG.DE) or Axa (AXAF.PA). While he would favor a tie-up with a foreign rival, he wants to ensure Generali’s Italian identity is preserved, the sources said.
description: Mediobanca should rely less on contributions from the investment bank's consumer credit unit and its stake in insurer Generali in a business plan due to be unveiled next month, shareholder Leonardo Del Vecchio said on Wednesday.
